p2: Enter individual video durations in hours, minutes, and seconds format (like 1:23:45 or 12:30), or paste a YouTube playlist URL to automatically pull all video lengths. Click calculate to see total watch time at standard 1x speed and at four faster speeds: 1.25x, 1.5x, 1.75x, and 2x playback. The tool displays results in hours and minutes, showing exactly how much clock time you'll spend watching the content at each speed. Add or remove videos to model different viewing scenarios. All calculations happen in your browser without sending your playlist data anywhere.
p3: Students with online lecture playlists calculate time commitments for exam preparation, discovering they can watch a 10-hour course in just 5 hours at 2x speed. Online course consumers preview total time investment before purchasing lengthy video courses to ensure they fit learning goals into busy schedules. Podcast listeners converting to YouTube video versions estimate realistic completion times when binging entire series. Conference attendees catching up on recorded talks calculate whether they can finish sessions before early-bird ticket deadlines by adjusting playback speed.
p4: Most people can comfortably comprehend 1.5x speed after a brief adjustment period, saving 33% of watch time with minimal comprehension loss. Technical content with dense information works better at 1.25x, while casual vlogs or entertainment can handle 2x. YouTube Premium is required for background playback and app-based speed controls on mobile; browser viewers can always adjust speed. Certain content types like music performances or cinematography-focused videos shouldn't be sped up as it degrades the experience. Combine speed watching with chapter markers or timestamps to skip irrelevant sections entirely for maximum time efficiency.
